Begović started his professional career with English club [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]], signing for them in the summer of 2003. After a sequence of loans, he made his Premier League debut in May 2009 and was sold to [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] for £3.25 million in February 2010. In the [[2012–13 Stoke City F.C. season|2012–13 season]] he played every league match and won the [[Stoke City F.C. Player of the Year|club's Player of the Year award]]. In November 2013 Begović became the fifth goalkeeper to score a goal in the Premier League, scoring from 97.5 yards against Southampton after 13 seconds, also getting the World Record for 'longest goal scored in football.' In July 2015, he joined Premier League champions [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] for a fee of £8 million, remaining second-choice until his move to Bournemouth two years later.
Begović represented [[Canada national football team|Canada]] at youth level playing for them at the [[2007 FIFA U-20 World Cup]]. In 2009, he decided to change his allegiance and represent his native country, [[Bosnia and Herzegovina national football team|Bosnia and Herzegovina]]. He soon established himself as their number one goalkeeper and helped them qualify for the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]], their first major tournament.
==Club career== ===Early career=== Begović was born in [[Trebinje]], Bosnia and Herzegovina, which was at the time part of Yugoslavia, to a [[Bosniak]] family.<ref>{{cite news|title=Asmir's world settled at last|url=http://slam.canoe.ca/Slam/Columnists/Lankhof/2007/07/01/4305227-sun.html|publisher=Sun Media Corp.|author=Bill Lankhof|date=1 July 2007|accessdate=9 November 2009}}</ref> His father, Amir, was also a goalkeeper who played for [[FK Leotar|Leotar]] and [[NK Iskra Bugojno|Iskra Bugojno]] whilst his mother, Ajnija, hails from [[Stolac]]. The Begović family fled the [[Bosnian War]] to Germany when Asmir was four years old, where he began to play organised football with local youth club FC Kirchhausen in [[Heilbronn]]. When he was 10, his family moved to [[Edmonton]] in Canada.<ref>{{cite web|title=Asmir and Nicolle Begovic: 'I think we've found the perfect match'|url=http://www.stokesentinel.co.uk/Asmir-Nicolle-Begovic-think-ve-perfect-match/story-13745097-detail/story.html|work=Stoke Sentinel|accessdate=26 December 2013}}</ref>
Begović attended the [[St. Francis Xavier High School (Edmonton)|St. Francis Xavier High School]] where he played for their academy.<ref name="Cansoc">{{cite web|title=article on Asmir Begovic|url=http://www.cansoc.org/archive/index.php/t-21455.html|work=cansoc.org|accessdate=28 December 2013}}</ref> He also played Minor League Soccer with the Southwest Sting Soccer Club in Edmonton which earned him a call-up to the [[Canada men's national youth soccer teams|Canada under-17 squad]].<ref name="Cansoc"/> In 2003, he earned a trial with [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]] and [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] and his representatives paid for him to fly over to England.<ref name="Pompey News">{{cite web|title=Pompey set to lose out again on keeper|url=http://www.portsmouth.co.uk/opinion/pompey-set-to-lose-out-again-on-keeper-1-5666594|work=Portsmouth News|accessdate=28 December 2013}}</ref> After two days with Portsmouth coaches David Hurst and [[Mark O'Connor (footballer)|Mark O'Connor]] were suitably impressed and offered Begović a contract before his trial at Tottenham could begin.<ref name="Pompey News"/>
===Portsmouth=== Begović signed a youth contract with [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]] in the summer of 2003 and due to him not having a European Union passport he spent two years on an education visa which prevented him from featuring in matches which involved money being taken on the gate.<ref name="Pompey News"/> After playing for the youth team he then spent time on loan at [[R.A.A. Louviéroise|La Louviere]] in Belgium in 2005 where he played twice in the Belgian top flight.<ref name="Pompey News"/> Begović got his [[Visa (document)|UK visa]] in the summer of 2006 which allowed him to sign on [[loan (association football)|loan]] for [[Macclesfield Town F.C.|Macclesfield Town]] in the [[2006–07 in English football|2006–07]] season, making his [[The Football League|Football League]] debut in a 1–1 draw at [[Stockport County F.C.|Stockport County]] on 25 November as an 80th minute [[substitute (association football)|substitute]], after injury to first choice goalkeeper [[Jonny Brain]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.mtfc.co.uk/page/MatchReport/0,,10393~34413,00.html|title=Stockport vs Macclesfield|accessdate=22 November 2010|publisher=mtfc.co.uk|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111006054741/http://www.mtfc.co.uk/page/MatchReport/0%2C%2C10393~34413%2C00.html|archivedate=6 October 2011}}</ref> His loan spell was cut short, however, as he sustained a knee injury after making just three appearances.<ref>{{cite news|title=Begovic ends Silkmen stay|url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11674_2399002,00.html|publisher=Sky Sports|date=21 December 2006|accessdate=19 August 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929121224/http://www.skysports.com/story/0%2C19528%2C11674_2399002%2C00.html|archivedate=29 September 2007|deadurl=no}}</ref> In August 2007, Begović was loaned to [[AFC Bournemouth]] in [[EFL League One|League One]] in a deal lasting until January 2008.<ref>{{cite news|title=Bournemouth sign quartet on loan|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/6939920.stm|publisher=BBC Sport|date=10 August 2007|accessdate=19 August 2007}}</ref> He was recalled back from Bournemouth on 11 October 2007.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/7040054.stm|title=Pair leave Cherries as loans end|accessdate=22 November 2010|publisher=BBC Sport|date=11 October 2007}}</ref> On 8 December 2007, Begović was named in Portsmouth's 16-man matchday squad for the first time in a [[Premier League]] game in a match against [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] as a substitute.<ref>{{cite web|title=Aston Villa 1–3 Portsmouth|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/7122767.stm|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=23 March 2013}}</ref>
In March 2008, he signed for [[Yeovil Town F.C.|Yeovil Town]] on loan for a month with Portsmouth having the right to recall him back when they so desired.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/7317449.stm|title=Yeovil loan Premier League pair|accessdate=22 November 2010|publisher=BBC Sport|date=27 March 2008}}</ref> On 29 March Begović made his debut for Yeovil, keeping a clean sheet against [[Bristol Rovers F.C.|Bristol Rovers]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Begovic happy with Glovers debut|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/7322342.stm|publisher=BBC Sport|date=31 March 2008|accessdate=14 April 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/7309334.stm|title=Yeovil 0–0 Bristol Rovers|accessdate=22 November 2010|publisher=BBC Sport|date=29 March 2008}}</ref> He was subsequently recalled after making two appearances despite Yeovil trying to re-sign him on an emergency loan.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/7340659.stm|title=Glovers fail in Begovic loan bid|accessdate=22 November 2010|publisher=BBC Sport|date=10 April 2008}}</ref> The "Glovers" manager [[Russell Slade]] revealed in June 2008 that he wanted to sign Begović on loan again after [[Steve Mildenhall]] joined Southend United.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/7440414.stm|title=Yeovil target Begovic loan deal|accessdate=22 November 2010|publisher=BBC Sport|date=6 June 2008}}</ref> The move was delayed however due to his grandfather passing away.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/7529552.stm|title=Begovic return to Yeovil delayed|accessdate=22 November 2010|publisher=BBC Sport|date=29 July 2008}}</ref> He rejoined Yeovil on loan, this time for three months in August 2008.<ref>{{cite news|title=Keeper Begovic agrees Yeovil loan|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/y/yeovil/7540726.stm|publisher=BBC Sport|date=7 August 2008|accessdate=11 February 2014}}</ref> He made 14 league appearances, keeping three clean sheets in a struggling Yeovil side.
Begović made his Portsmouth debut against Sunderland in their 3–1 win on 18 May 2009.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/8038304.stm|title=Portsmouth 3–1 Sunderland|accessdate=22 November 2010|publisher=BBC Sport|first=Phil|last=Dawkes|date=18 May 2009}}</ref> Following his Premier League debut for Pompey Begović expressed his delight. "It was fantastic, to make your first Premier League appearance is something I've looked forward to for a long long time."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/8057377.stm|title=Begovic happy with Pompey debut|accessdate=22 November 2010|publisher=BBC Sport|date=19 May 2009}}</ref> He joined [[EFL Championship|Championship]] team [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]] on loan until 16 January 2010 in October.<ref>{{cite news|title=Premier keeper arrives on loan|url=http://www.itfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10272~1826420,00.html|publisher=Ipswich Town F.C.|date=14 October 2009|accessdate=14 October 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111004083324/http://www.itfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10272~1826420%2C00.html|archivedate=4 October 2011}}</ref> On 23 November Begović was recalled to Portsmouth due to [[David James (footballer)|David James]] being injured, ending his Ipswich Town loan after having played six matches.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/8374039.stm|title=Portsmouth recall keeper Begovic|accessdate=22 November 2010|publisher=BBC Sport|date=23 November 2009}}</ref> On his return to [[Fratton Park]] he went on to play 15 first team matches during the [[2009–10 Portsmouth F.C. season|2009–10 season]].
===Stoke City=== [[File:Asmir Begovic.jpg|thumb|upright|Begović playing for [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] in 2011]]
On 1 February 2010, Begović signed a four-and-a-half-year contract at [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] for a fee of £3.25 million.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/8488595.stm|title=Stoke sign Portsmouth keeper Asmir Begovic|accessdate=11 January 2011|publisher=BBC Sport|date=1 February 2010}}</ref> Following the signing manager [[Tony Pulis]] revealed that he had been tracking Begović for a while. "We have been tracking Asmir for some time and we believe that potentially he is the best young keeper in the country".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.stokecityfc.com/page/NewsDetail/0,,10310~1952377,00.html|title=Begovic One of the Best–Pulis|accessdate=22 November 2010|publisher=stokecityfc.com|date=1 February 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100204033759/http://www.stokecityfc.com/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10310~1952377%2C00.html|archivedate=4 February 2010}}</ref> Begović had also held talks with [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] prior to joining Stoke, but opted for the "Potters" due to "sporting reasons".<ref>{{cite web|title=Asmir Begovic relieved to leave Portsmouth for Stoke|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/8512831.stm|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=1 February 2013|date=12 February 2010}}</ref> He later revealed his relief at leaving [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]] following their financial turmoil during the [[2009–10 Stoke City F.C. season|2009–10 season]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Begovic relieved to leave Pompey|url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11095_5918562,00.html|publisher=SkySports|date=1 April 2010|accessdate=1 April 2010}}</ref> Portsmouth ended up owing Tottenham money for Begović, despite him turning them down, as Tottenham had already paid Portsmouth an instalment on the transfer.<ref>{{cite news|title=Tottenham stand by £1m demand to Portsmouth for Begovic|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/8636703.stm|publisher=BBC Sport|date=23 April 2010}}</ref> Portsmouth were ordered to pay Tottenham £1 million by the [[Premier League]] over the aborted transfer as Spurs had already made an initial payment for both Begović and [[Younès Kaboul]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/9009799.stm|title=Portsmouth ordered to pay Tottenham over Asmir Begovic|accessdate=4 June 2011|publisher=BBC Sport|date=17 September 2010}}</ref>
Begović made his debut for Stoke against [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] on 25 April 2010, replacing the injured [[Thomas Sørensen]] in the 35th minute, where he conceded five goals.<ref>{{cite news|title=Chelsea 7–0 Stoke|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/8632297.stm|publisher=BBC Sport|date=25 April 2010}}</ref> He kept his first clean sheet for City in a 0–0 draw with [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] on 1 May 2010.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/8648890.stm|title=Stoke 0–0 Everton|accessdate=5 May 2010|work=BBC|publisher=BBC Sport|date=1 May 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100503144340/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/8648890.stm|archivedate=3 May 2010|deadurl=no}}</ref> He also played in the last two games of the 2009–10 season against [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] and [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]].
At the start of the [[2010–11 Stoke City F.C. season|2010–11 season]] Begović was handed the number one jersey by manager [[Tony Pulis]]. Begović allegedly refused to play in a [[EFL Cup|League Cup]] match against [[Shrewsbury Town F.C.|Shrewsbury Town]], a decision which Pulis said was "totally disrespectful".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/8941790.stm|title=Stoke boss Tony Pulis unhappy with keeper Asmir Begovic|accessdate=25 August 2010|publisher=BBC Sport|date=26 August 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100827022655/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/8941790.stm|archivedate=27 August 2010|deadurl=no}}</ref> Begović on the other hand, denied that he had refused to play.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/8954598.stm|title=Asmir Begovic denies Stoke City 'strike' claim|accessdate=30 October 2010|publisher=BBC Sport|date=30 August 2010}}</ref> Despite this Begović played his first match of the season in the next round of the League Cup against Fulham and then [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]]. He made his first league appearance on 30 October against Everton replacing the injured Sørensen.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/9136334.stm|title=Everton 1–0 Stoke|accessdate=30 October 2010|publisher=BBC Sport|date=30 October 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101030152104/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/9136334.stm|archivedate=30 October 2010|deadurl=no}}</ref> Following this Begović took over from Sørensen as City's first choice 'keeper, he also 'made peace' with Tony Pulis with his absence from the Shrewsbury match.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thisisstaffordshire.co.uk/sport/Stoke-City-Begovic-playing-keeps/article-2924281-detail/article.html|title=Asmir Begovic wants long-term Potters stay|accessdate=23 November 2010|publisher=thisisstaffordshire.co.uk|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101126114004/http://www.thisisstaffordshire.co.uk/sport/Stoke-City-Begovic-playing-keeps/article-2924281-detail/article.html|archivedate=26 November 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/9355662.stm|title=Tony Pulis row behind me, says Stoke's Asmir Begovic|accessdate=11 January 2011|publisher=BBC Sport|first=Sam|last=Sheringham|date=11 January 2011}}</ref> After a narrow defeat at [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] in February 2011 Begović believes that Stoke are developing well.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/9407129.stm|title=Stoke City are developing well–keeper Asmir Begovic|accessdate=27 February 2011|publisher=BBC Sport|date=25 February 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110303073636/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/9407129.stm|archivedate=3 March 2011|deadurl=no}}</ref> The following week against West Ham, Begović made an error gifting a goal to [[Demba Ba]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/9416177.stm|title=Stoke boss Tony Pulis backs Asmir Begovic after error|accessdate=4 June 2011|publisher=BBC Sport|date=6 March 2011}}</ref> Begović missed out on a [[FA Cup Final]] with second choice 'keeper Sørensen being preferred to play in cup matches.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/9468359.stm|title=Stoke goalkeeper Asmir Begovic accepts FA Cup omission|accessdate=4 June 2011|publisher=BBC Sport|date=26 April 2011}}</ref>
Begović started the [[2011–12 Stoke City F.C. season|2011–12 season]] as first choice keeper and earned praise from Tony Pulis after he kept five clean sheets in six matches including a fine display against [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] on 11 September.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/14912788.stm|title=More to come from Stoke's Asmir Begovic–Tony Pulis|accessdate=14 September 2011|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> However, Begović then conceded eighteen goals in the next seven matches, including a woeful 5–0 defeat by Bolton Wanderers a performance which led him to apologise to the supporters for his display.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thisisstaffordshire.co.uk/story-13778967-detail/story.html|title=Begovic apologises for Bolton hammering|accessdate=7 November 2011|publisher=The Sentinel}}</ref> Following the Bolton match he was dropped in favour of Sørensen.<ref>{{cite web|title='We Answered Questions Today'-Sorensen|url=http://www.stokecityfc.com/page/NewsDetail/0,,10310~2528787,00.html|work=Stoke City F.C.|accessdate=6 December 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111129052639/http://www.stokecityfc.com/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10310~2528787%2C00.html|archivedate=29 November 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title='Busy' Begovic playing for top job|url=http://www.thisisstaffordshire.co.uk/Stoke-City-Busy-Begovic-playing-job/story-14145705-detail/story.html|work=The Senitnel|accessdate=17 December 2011}}</ref> Begović signed a new four-and-a-half year contract extension with Stoke in December 2011 keeping him at the club until 2016.<ref>{{cite web|title=Stoke City's Thomas Sorensen and Asmir Begovic sign new deals|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/16271990|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=20 July 2013|date=20 December 2011}}</ref> He regained number 1 spot in March 2012.<ref>{{cite web|title=Stoke City's Asmir Begovic desperate for FA Cup start|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17365499|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=17 August 2012}}</ref> Begović continued as City's number one stopper in [[2012–13 Stoke City F.C. season|2012–13]] and began the season in fine form conceding just 12 goals in the opening 15 matches.<ref>{{cite web|title=Asmir Begovic happy at Stoke City despite Liverpool and Manchester United rumours|url=http://www.thisisstaffordshire.co.uk/story-17503387-detail/story.html?|work=The Sentinel|accessdate=5 December 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Asmir Begovic: Stoke City record down to being organised|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/20679917|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=2 February 2013}}</ref> Despite Stoke having a poor second half to the season, Begović remained in decent enough form and won the [[Stoke City F.C. Player of the Year|Player of the Year Award]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Asmir Begovic sweeps the board at club awards night|url=http://www.thisisstaffordshire.co.uk/story-18990384-detail/story.html?#axzz2TJEpSTc2|work=The Sentinel|accessdate=15 May 2013}}</ref>
Begović remained first choice 'keeper going into the [[2013–14 Stoke City F.C. season|2013–14]] season under new manager [[Mark Hughes]] and produced a [[man of the match]] performance on the opening day against [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Liverpool 1–0 Stoke|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23653990|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=4 September 2013}}</ref> On 2 November 2013, Begović scored after 13 seconds against [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] at a distance of 97.5 yards, after his long kick downfield deceived [[Artur Boruc]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Stoke 1–1 Southampton|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/24681360|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=2 November 2013}}</ref> His goal against earned him a place in the 2015 ''[[Guinness World Records]]'' for the 'longest goal scored in football'.<ref>{{cite web|title=Begovic Strike Enters The Guinness World Records Book|url=http://www.stokecityfc.com/news/article/begovic-strike-enters-the-guinness-world-records-book-1895598.aspx?|website=Stoke City F.C|accessdate=4 September 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Asmir Begovic inducted into Guinness Book of Records for long-distance goal|url=http://www.stokesentinel.co.uk/Stoke-City-Asmir-Begovic-inducted-Guinness-Book/story-22873150-detail/story.html?|website=Stoke Sentinel|accessdate=4 September 2014}}</ref>
{{quote|It's a cool feeling but it was a fortunate incident. I feel a bit bad for Boruc. It is a long ball that got caught in the wind and it took a wicked bounce. It's not nice to be on the receiving end of those things as a goalkeeper. It does not make a goalkeeper look good and after it I [[Goal celebration#Notable non-celebrations|did not want to celebrate]] out of respect for him.|Begović speaks after scoring against Southampton.<ref>{{cite web|title=Asmir Begovic: Stoke goalkeeper felt bad for Artur Boruc after goal|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/24790526|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=2 November 2013}}</ref>}}

===Chelsea=== [[File:Chelsea Vs Maccabi Tel-Aviv (20870322584).jpg|thumb|upright|Begović playing for [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] in 2015]]
On 13 July 2015, Chelsea signed Begović on a four-year deal for a fee of £8 million. As part of the deal Chelsea also offered midfielder [[Marco van Ginkel]] in part exchange to Stoke on loan for one season.<ref>{{cite web|title=Begovic transfer completed|url=https://www.chelseafc.com/news/latest-news/2015/07/begovic-transfer-completed.html|publisher=chelseafc.com|date=13 July 2015|accessdate=13 July 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/33270636|title=Asmir Begovic: Chelsea sign goalkeeper from Stoke City|publisher=bbc.com|date=13 July 2015|accessdate=13 July 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.com/story/2518524/chelsea-offer-van-ginkel-in-new-asmir-begovic-bid-sources|title=Chelsea offer Van Ginkel to Stoke in new Asmir Begovic bid|publisher=espnfc.com|date=10 July 2015|accessdate=14 July 2015}}</ref>
He made his debut nine days later on Chelsea's pre-season tour, coming on at half time for [[Thibaut Courtois]] with Chelsea 1–0 up against the [[New York Red Bulls]], but the match ended in a 2–4 defeat. Manager [[José Mourinho]] defended Begović's performance, attributing it to fatigue.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Draper|first1=Rob|title=Jose Mourinho defends £8m keeper Asmir Begovic after debut errors as Chelsea are beaten by New York Red Bulls|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-3171708/Jose-Mourinho-defends-8m-keeper-Asmir-Begovic-debut-errors-Chelsea-beaten-New-York-Red-Bulls.html|accessdate=23 July 2015|work=Daily Mail|date=23 July 2015}}</ref> His first competitive fixture was the [[2015 FA Community Shield]] on 2 August at [[Wembley Stadium]], in which he was unused in a 1–0 loss to [[Arsenal F.C.–Chelsea F.C. rivalry|rivals]] [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Cryer|first1=Andy|title=Arsenal 1–0 Chelsea|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/33667216|accessdate=2 August 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=2 August 2015}}</ref> Six days later he came on as a substitute for [[Oscar (footballer, born 1991)|Oscar]] when Courtois was sent off for conceding a penalty with a foul on [[Bafétimbi Gomis]], who converted it for a 2–2 draw.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Johnston|first1=Neil|title=Chelsea 2–2 Swansea|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/33744668|accessdate=8 August 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=8 August 2015}}</ref> On 16 August, Begović made his first competitive start for Chelsea in a 3–0 away loss to [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Manchester City 3–0 Chelsea|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/33839794|accessdate=16 August 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=16 August 2015}}</ref> A month later, he earned the first clean sheet of the season for Chelsea in a [[UEFA Champions League]] match against [[Maccabi Tel Aviv F.C.|Maccabi Tel Aviv]] which ended in a 4–0 win for Chelsea.<ref>{{cite news|title=Chelsea 4–0 Maccabi Tel Aviv|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/34203636|accessdate=16 September 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=16 September 2015}}</ref> He kept a sequence of three clean sheets before Courtois returned to the team on 5 December.<ref>{{cite news|title=Chelsea 0–1 Bournemouth: Late Murray winner stuns Blues|url=http://www.goal.com/en-au/match/chelsea-vs-afc-bournemouth/2043202/report|accessdate=5 December 2015|publisher=goal.com|date=5 December 2015}}</ref>
In his second season with Chelsea, Begović didn't get much playing time, and there were speculations that he would leave the club in the winter transfer window. However, since Chelsea couldn't find a replacement for him, he was forced to stay at [[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://scsport.ba/begovic-nervira-me-sto-ne-dobijam-dovoljno-prilika/|title=Begović: Nervira me što ne dobijam dovoljno prilika|website=scsport.ba|date=7 February 2017|accessdate=23 February 2017|language=Bosnian}}</ref> In spite of featuring in only two league games, he received a winners' medal as Chelsea won the [[2016–17 Premier League]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11668/10879368/chelsea-confirm-asmir-begovic-will-receive-a-premier-league-medal|title=Chelsea confirm that Asmir Begović will receive a Premier League medal|first=Gary|last=Cotterill|website=skysports.com|date=15 May 2017|accessdate=2 January 2018}}</ref>
===AFC Bournemouth=== On 30 May 2017, Begović signed for Premier League club Bournemouth on a long-term contract for an undisclosed fee.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40098727|title=Asmir Begovic: Bournemouth sign keeper from champions Chelsea|publisher=bbc.co.uk|date=30 May 2017|accessdate=30 May 2017}}</ref> He debuted for Bournemouth on the opening day of the new Premier League season, in a 0–1 loss against [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/match-centre/west-brom-bournemouth-live-score-10622606|title=WBA 1–0 Bournemouth: Ahmed Hegazi heads in debut winner to down Cherries|website=mirror.co.uk|date=12 August 2017|accessdate=13 August 2017}}</ref> Begović kept his first clean sheet in the season on 30 September, in a 0–0 draw against [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/sep/30/bournemouth-leicester-city-premier-league-match-report|title=Bournemouth stay in bottom three after failing to break down Leicester|website=theguardian.com|date=30 September 2017|accessdate=26 February 2018}}</ref> He had another impressive performance, this time against his former club Chelsea, which Bournemouth won 3–0.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-5336545/Chelsea-0-3-Bournemouth-Contes-champions-meltdown.html|title=Chelsea 0–3 Bournemouth: Antonio Conte's champions go into meltdown as Nathan Ake comes back to haunt his former side at Stamford Bridge|website=dailymail.co.uk|date=31 January 2018|accessdate=26 February 2018}}</ref>
==International career== ===Canada=== Begović was the starting goalkeeper for [[Canada men's national soccer team|Canada]] in the [[2007 FIFA U-20 World Cup]]. He made several difficult saves for his team in a 3–0 loss to [[Chile national under-20 football team|Chile]] and let in one goal against [[Austria national under-19 football team|Austria]]. Late in the third match of the tournament, after allowing two goals, Begović came out of his area to play a long ball from a [[DR Congo national under-20 football team|Congo]] defender. The ball took a high bounce off the wet pitch, forcing him to use his hands to prevent it from going over his head. He was shown a straight red card, and midfielder [[Jonathan Beaulieu-Bourgault]] was forced to play in goal, as Canada had used up its three substitutes.<ref>{{cite news|title=New number one for Canada fans|url=https://www.fifa.com/tournaments/archive/u20worldcup/canada2007/news/newsid=549236.html#new+number+canada+fans|publisher=fifa.com|date=9 July 2007|accessdate=4 November 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090408081919/http://www.fifa.com/tournaments/archive/u20worldcup/canada2007/news/newsid%3D549236.html|archivedate=8 April 2009|deadurl=yes}}</ref>
On 14 August 2007, 20-year-old Begović received his first call-up to the senior Canada squad for the friendly match with [[Iceland national football team|Iceland]], but didn't see any action on the pitch.<ref>{{cite news|title=Mitchell and Canada to face Iceland|url=https://www.tsn.ca/soccer/news_story/?ID=216145&hubname=soccer|publisher=Canadian Press|date=14 August 2007|accessdate=19 August 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929164545/http://www.tsn.ca/soccer/news_story/?ID=216145&hubname=soccer|archivedate=29 September 2007}}</ref> In November 2008, he accepted another call for Canada's [[2010 FIFA World Cup]] [[2010 FIFA World Cup qualification – CONCACAF Third Round|qualifier]] versus Jamaica, but again didn't get any playing time as [[Lars Hirschfeld]] was the preferred option in goal.
Players with dual nationality, like Begović, who had already played for a country's national team at youth level, were not allowed to switch nationalities after they turned 21, but on 3 June 2009 FIFA removed the age limit.<ref>{{cite web|last=Evans|first=Simon|title=Soccer-FIFA removes age limit on players switching nations|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2009/06/03/soccer-fifa-switching-idUKL317735320090603|work=Reuters.com|publisher=Thomson Reuters|accessdate=7 October 2013}}</ref> In late June 2009, he spoke with Bosnian head coach [[Miroslav Blažević]] about the possibility of making his debut for [[Bosnia and Herzegovina national football team|Bosnia and Herzegovina]]. Quotes in the Bosnian media seemed to indicate Begović's intent to play for the country of his birth.<ref>{{cite news|title=Begović: Ćiro mi je obećao da će me zvati|url=http://sportsport.ba/bh_fudbalp-19424.htm|publisher=SportSport.ba|date=24 June 2009|accessdate=24 June 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090626013453/http://sportsport.ba/bh_fudbalp-19424.htm|archivedate=26 June 2009}}</ref> Begović missed the [[2009 CONCACAF Gold Cup]] for Canada saying Portsmouth wanted him to spend the whole pre-season with the club. On 12 July 2009 on ''[[Full-Time: Vancouver's Soccer Show]]'' on the [[CKST|TEAM 1040]] radio in Canada he indicated his desire to continue with the Canadian national team. He suggested that comments he had made to Bosnia's head coach had been misinterpreted due to poor translation. In the same interview, Begović also said:
{{quote|I've played for Canada for a long time. There's no decision, I don't want to switch... but there is a state of uncertainty with Canada soccer (next coach, etc). Get things in place and I'm happy to stay with Canada, that's where I see my future... I've been approached by Bosnia. There were talks... but I have no intention on playing for Bosnia.<ref>{{cite news|title=Begovic: "I don't want to switch"|url=http://fulltimefootballshow.blogspot.com/2009/07/begovic-i-dont-want-to-switch.html|publisher=fulltimefootballshow|date=13 July 2009|accessdate=13 July 2009}}</ref>}}
===Bosnia and Herzegovina===
However, less than two months later, Begović changed his mind and on 21 August 2009 accepted a call-up for two Bosnia [[2010 FIFA World Cup qualification – UEFA Group 5|2010 World Cup qualifiers]]: away at [[Armenia national football team|Armenia]] on 5 September 2009, and four days later versus [[Turkey national football team|Turkey]] at home in [[Zenica]]. During the pre-match preparations, Begović gave an interview to the Bosnian web portal, stating among other things:
{{quote|I was born in Trebinje, Bosnia and Herzegovina is my homeland and I wouldn't be disappointed even if I don't get a chance to play right away.<ref>{{cite news|title=Ako i ne dobijem šansu, neću biti razočaran|url=http://sarajevo-x.com/sport/nogomet/clanak/090904063|publisher=sarajevo-x.com|date=4 September 2009|accessdate=21 November 2009}}</ref>}}
He did not play in either match. However, his debut for the national team finally came in the next qualifier against [[Estonia national football team|Estonia]]. He came on to replace [[Kenan Hasagić]] in the 92nd minute of the match, in which Bosnia won the match with a final score of 2–0.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://uk.eurosport.yahoo.com/football/world-cup/2010/estonia-bosnia-herzegovina-249429.html|title=Estonia v Bosnia-Herzegovina|publisher=Yahoo! Sport|accessdate=10 October 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091012162454/http://uk.eurosport.yahoo.com/football/world-cup/2010/estonia-bosnia-herzegovina-249429.html|archivedate=12 October 2009|deadurl=no}}</ref>
On 3 March he played a significant role in a match for the first time as he got to play the second half in Bosnia's [[Exhibition game|friendly]] match against [[Ghana national football team|Ghana]]. Bosnia won the match 2–1 and Begović didn't concede any goals.<ref>{{cite news|title=Bosnia-Herzegovina 2–1 Ghana|url=http://www.goal.com/en/news/1863/world-cup-2010/2010/03/03/1816436/bosnia-herzegovina-2-1-ghana-dragons-rally-to-defeat-black|publisher=Goal.com|accessdate=3 March 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100414035448/http://goal.com/en/news/1863/world-cup-2010/2010/03/03/1816436/bosnia-herzegovina-2-1-ghana-dragons-rally-to-defeat-black|archivedate=14 April 2010|deadurl=no}}</ref> He received his first full cap against [[Sweden national football team|Sweden]] in May 2010. Bosnia lost the match 4–2, but Begović was not responsible for any of the goals according to the Bosnian media, as they blamed Bosnia's defense for the goals.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.11v11.com/matches/sweden-v-bosnia-and-herzegovina-29-may-2010-289313/|title=Sweden 4–2 Bosnia}}</ref> He caused controversy after he pulled out of Bosnia's friendlies against [[Slovakia national football team|Slovakia]] and [[Mexico national football team|Mexico]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/9398677.stm|title=Stoke resolve row with Bosnian FA over Asmir Begovic|accessdate=18 February 2011|publisher=BBC Sport|date=16 February 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110224071708/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/9398677.stm|archivedate=24 February 2011|deadurl=no}}</ref>
Since August 2012, Begović has been the first choice goalkeeper for the national team. On 27 May 2013, Begović has been voted the 2012 Bosnian Footballer of the Year by the Bosnian Sport Writers' Jury.<ref>{{cite web|title=Begović named Bosnian idol|url=http://www.uefa.com/memberassociations/association=bih/news/newsid=1961955.html|publisher=uefa.com|accessdate=20 July 2013}}</ref> On 16 October 2013 Bosnia defeated [[Lithuania national football team|Lithuania]] 1–0 to qualify for the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]], their first major tournament.<ref>{{cite web|title=Asmir Begovic: Bosnia goalkeeper plans World Cup upsets|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/24574103|publisher=bbc.co.uk|accessdate=18 October 2013}}</ref>
In June 2014, he was named in Bosnia and Herzegovina's squad for the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]]<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/bosnia-and-herzegovina/10810419/Bosnia-Herzegovina-World-Cup-2014-squad.html|title=Bosnia and Herzegovina 2014 World Cup Squad|date=2 June 2014|accessdate=20 June 2014|work=The Telegraph}}</ref> where he played full 90 minutes in all 3 matches.
==Personal life== On 18 June 2011, Begović married his American-born wife, Nicolle Howard, with whom he has two daughters, Taylor and Blair Rose Begović.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thisisstaffordshire.co.uk/Asmir-Nicolle-Begovic-think-ve-perfect-match/story-13745097-detail/story.html#axzz2ZJtMAyOf|title=Asmir and Nicolle Begovic: 'I think we've found the perfect match'|website=thisisstaffordshire.co.uk|date=8 July 2012|accessdate=20 July 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thisisstaffordshire.co.uk/Stoke-City-star-Asmir-Begovic-takes-time-open-new/story-19259690-detail/story.html#axzz2ZJtMAyOftitle=Stoke City star Asmir Begovic takes time out to open new building at daughter's school|website=thisisstaffordshire.co.uk|date=10 July 2012|accessdate=20 July 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://sportsport.ba/magazin/asmir-begovic-postao-otac/226175|title=Asmir Begović po drugi put postao otac!|publisher=sportsport.ba|date=23 February 2017|accessdate=3 March 2017|language=Bosnian}}</ref> In April 2011 he joined [[FC Edmonton]]'s charity 'Kicks for Kids Program'.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oursportscentral.com/services/releases/?id=4177305|title=Kicks for Kids Program Gets a Boost From a Soccer Star|website=oursportscentral.com|date=4 April 2011|accessdate=29 December 2013}}</ref>
Begović was born in Bosnia and Herzegovina while it was part of the SFR Yugoslavia, and moved to Germany at the age of four.<ref name="Asmir Begovic: World Cup can reunite Bosnia's golden generation">{{cite news|last=Wilson|first=Steve|title=Asmir Begovic: World Cup can reunite Bosnia's 'golden generation'|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/27442963|accessdate=28 May 2014|newspaper=BBC Sports|date=27 May 2014}}</ref> Growing up in Germany, Begović supported [[FC Bayern Munich|Bayern Munich]] and cites goalkeeping great [[Oliver Kahn]] as his inspiration. He also attended matches at his local club [[VfB Stuttgart]].<ref>Stoke City Official Matchday Magazine 24 September 2011 v Manchester United</ref> Along with his native [[Bosnian language|Bosnian]], Begović is fluent in three additional languages: [[German language|German]], [[English language|English]] and [[French language|French]].<ref>[http://scsport.ba/vijest/50496 Begović izabrao: RVP i Mata najbolji u Premiershipu, protiv CR7 bilo je najteže, Kahn najveći...] {{hr icon}}</ref> In October 2013 he set up his own charity, the Asmir Begović Foundation.<ref>{{cite web|title=Asmir Begovic Foundation|url=http://www.asmirbegovicfoundation.com/|work=ABF|accessdate=22 October 2013}}</ref>
Begović's younger brother Denis plays for [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City's]] Under 18s as a goalkeeper.<ref>{{cite web|title=Denis Begovic Player Profile|url=https://www.bcfc.co.uk/teams/under-18s-squad/denis-begovic/|work=Bristol City|accessdate=12 September 2018}}</ref>
